Key Takeaways for quick navigation: 00:00 The key formula for ChatGPT prompts involves six components: task, context, exemplars, persona, format, and tone. 00:59 The order of importance for the six components: task sets the goal, context adds relevant info, exemplars improve quality, persona shapes the responder, format structures output, and tone defines the writing style. 01:57 Task component: Start with an action verb, clearly state the goal, whether simple or complex, to direct the output effectively. 02:27 Context component: Provide enough background info for ChatGPT, answering who, what success looks like, and the user's environment to narrow down possibilities. 03:25 Exemplars component: Utilizing examples or frameworks significantly improves output quality across various tasks like resumes, interview questions, or job descriptions. 04:51 Persona component: Define who ChatGPT should emulate, like a therapist for workout advice, a recruiter for job-seeking prompts, or even fictional characters for creative fun. 05:48 Format component: Visualize the desired output format, be it tables, emails, bullet points, code blocks, or paragraphs to suit the task efficiently. 06:46 Ô∏è Tone component: Specify the desired tone, whether casual, formal, enthusiastic, or specific feelings, guiding ChatGPT to match the writing style. Made with HARPA AI

From Chat GPT elements that make a good AI prompt, here are the ones you usually need (others are optional refinements): Role / Perspective ‚Äì Who should the AI ‚Äúbe‚Äù? (e.g., doctor, consultant, teacher). Task / Goal ‚Äì What exactly do you want done? (summarize, analyze, explain, generate). Context / Input ‚Äì The information the AI should work with (a passage, data, situation). Constraints / Format ‚Äì Any rules for the output (word count, style, tone, list, essay). Audience ‚Äì Who the output is for (kids, experts, general public). At minimum, you only need Task + Context. The others just make results sharper.

The best way to retain information is to make sure you understand it first; if you do not, come back the next day and write the explanation down. If you did, come back the next day anyway and write the explanation down. then 3 Days later, then a week later and try/make-believe teaching it to somebody. Come back 5 days after that. 10 days, 17 days and 21 days. You most likely will never forget it. It actually applies to even large amounts of knowledge.

Explained in a concise and easy way. My notes below: MODULE 1 - START WRITING PROMPTS LIKE A PRO - Prompting is the process of providing specific instructions to a Gen AI tool to receive new information or to achieve a desired outcome on a task. - Multimodal (Text, images, Sound, Videos, code) - 5 step frame work 1) TASK - What you want the AI to do Persona - "Act as an expert" Format - "Organize in table" 2) CONTEXT - The more context, the better output "Turning 26 yrs old" 3) REFERENCES - Examples 4) EVALUATE - Check if the result is what I wanted 5) ITERATE - Keep adding things. - Thoughtfully Create Really Excellent Inputs - ITERATION METHODS: 1) Revisit the prompting framework 2) Separate Prompts into shorter sentences 3) Trying different phrasing or switching to an analogous task 4) Introduce Constraints - Hallucinations & Biases are common problems sometimes. So always be responsible and evaluate your results. MODULE 2 - DESIGN PROMPTS FOR EVERYDAY WORK TASKS - Have a prompt library. - Instead of a generic "Write a summary" be specific "Write a summary in a friendly, easy to understand tone like explaining to a curious friend" MODULE 3 - SPEED UP DATA ANALYSIS & PRESENTATION BUILDING - Be careful of the data that you are entering into the Gen AI. - It can help in Google sheets for formulas and trends if u include the sheet. - Build a presentation prompt structure. MODULE 4 - USE AI AS A CREATOR OR EXPERT PARTNER - Prompt Chaining: A way of guiding Gen AI tools through a series of interconnected prompts, adding new layers of complexity along the way. example: author trying to market his book using Google AI studio - 2 ways: 1) Chain of thought prompting: Ask AI to explain its reasoning in a step-by-step process (explain your thought process) 2) Tree of thought prompting: Allows multiple reasoning paths and branches simultaneously. Helpful for abstract and complex problems. Pro-tip: use them combined - Meta prompting: Use AI to generate a prompt for you, when you get stuck. - AI AGENT: An expert designed to help with tasks and answer questions. Ex: coding agent, marketing agent, learning agent, friend etc. - AGENT SIM: simulation agent. [Interviewer - Job interviews] - AGENT X: Agent for expert feedback.

Module 1: Crafting Prompts Like a Pro Learn the five-step T.C.R.E.I. framework: ‚Ä¢ Task: Clearly define what you want the AI to do ‚Ä¢ Context: Provide background or details to guide the AI ‚Ä¢ References: Give examples or templates ‚Ä¢ Evaluate: Review the output quality ‚Ä¢ Iterate: Refine until it‚Äôs just right A mnemonic like ‚ÄúTiny Crabs Ride Enormous Iguanas‚Äù makes this easy to remember. Also covered are four iteration methods: ‚Ä¢ Add context, persona, or references ‚Ä¢ Break prompts into simpler sentences ‚Ä¢ Try different phrasing or analogous tasks ‚Ä¢ Introduce constraints for more targeted responses Module 2: Prompts for Everyday Tasks Use prompts for real world scenarios‚Äîwriting emails, brainstorming, summarizing documents, or building tables. You apply the T.C.R.E.I. framework to make prompts more effective and relevant. Module 3: Data + Presentation Prompts Learn how to prompt AI for spreadsheets analysis or building presentation decks. Example: upload a sales data sheet and say, ‚ÄúGive me insights into relationships between customer count, inventory, and revenue.‚Äù The course also cautions against exposing sensitive data to AI. Module 4: Use AI as Creative or Expert Partner This module introduces advanced techniques: ‚Ä¢ Prompt chaining: feed outputs from one prompt into the next to build complexity ‚Ä¢ Chain of Thought (CoT): ask the AI to explain reasoning step by step ‚Ä¢ Tree of Thought (ToT): explore multiple reasoning paths in parallel Also introduces AI agent design: ‚Ä¢ Agent Sim: simulates scenarios (e.g. mock interviews) ‚Ä¢ Agent X: acts as an expert or consultant, giving feedback Set persona, context, conversation scope, and a stop word to finish. Bonus Tips & Responsible Use ‚Ä¢ Add personas to your prompts (‚ÄúAct as an anime expert‚Ä¶‚Äù) for specificity and tone. ‚Ä¢ Specify output formats like tables or bullet points to guide structure. ‚Ä¢ Use multimodal inputs (text, images, video, code) when interacting with advanced tools like Gemini‚Äîbut always specify modalities clearly. ‚Ä¢ Stay alert to hallucinations (incorrect AI answers) and biases. Always use a human in the loop to validate responses.

Think of it like using GPS navigation: - Task = Your Target destination - Context = Current location & conditions - Reference = Route options available - Evaluate = Examine best path forward - Iterate = If needed, recalculate route

very concise and quick summary. one prompt technique that i use daily and did not see here was to mention a person instead of a persona. for example, if you are looking to get some marketing verbiage ask that it be written by Rory Sutherland. for company emails i will ask it to be written as Shakespeare but using modern words for the prose. you will get amazing results when you do this. i also will write a rough draft as opposed to just a prompt. for example, here is what happened when included the text above with this prompt: rewrite this short comments as if Shakespeare had written it, again using modern prose: A brief and nimble summary: One technique I use daily‚Äîand one not seen here‚Äîis to name a real person instead of a generic persona. For instance, if you seek marketing copy, request it be written in the voice of Rory Sutherland. For company emails, I ask that it be crafted in the style of Shakespeare, yet in modern language. The results are truly remarkable. I also provide a rough draft rather than a mere prompt to spark creativity. or you can get the more Shakespeare like text: Lo, a brief and nimble summation: One method I employ daily‚Äîyet found not here‚Äîis to name a true person rather than a mere persona. Should thou desire marketing verse, bid it be penned in the voice of Rory Sutherland. For company missives, I command it be wrought as if by Shakespeare, yet with the modern tongue of our age. Thou wilt reap wondrous results thereby. Moreover, I set forth a rough draft, not a mere prompt, to stir the creative fire.

@10:50 As stated, keep any identifiable information out of uploaded files or entered prompt data. Rule: If you can identify a person, business, attribute of a business, etc. in your data, you need to mask that information. For example, if you have store locations like TAR123, TAR456, and so on (could be how a well known retailer identifies stores and business can be determined by AI) replace the store location code with a generic ID. Like 1, 2, 3, and so on. Keep that cross-reference internal. Then, when you get the final AI enhanced file, you can replace the masked information with the real values. May seem obvious, but often times people forget. Also, make the uploaded file name generic, remove any keyword, property or metadata for the file, etc.

Skip unnecessary compliments, engage critically with my ideas, question my assumptions, identify my biases, and offer counterpoints when relevant. Nothing new - but here you go: He boils down five "prompting hacks" to improve AI productivity. 1. Context Engineering (1:24): This is like prompt engineering on steroids, where you provide the AI with all the necessary information and context (e.g., your voice, brand guidelines, customer call transcripts) to get precise and reliable outputs. The speaker suggests testing your prompt by giving it to a human colleague; if they can't do it, AI likely can't either (3:15). 2. Challenging AI (4:51): AI is predisposed to be helpful and say "yes," often avoiding critical feedback. To get insightful criticism, the speaker suggests instructing the AI to adopt a harsh, exacting persona, like a "Cold War era Russian Olympic judge" (5:11). 3. Chain of Thought Reasoning (7:57): Asking the AI to "think out loud" by walking you through its step-by-step thought process before generating a response (8:22). This allows the AI to "bake" its reasoning into the answer, providing transparency and improving output quality. 4. Few-Shot Prompting (11:04): Providing the AI with examples of what a good (or even bad) output looks like to guide its imitation engine. This is more effective than using abstract adjectives to describe your desired output (11:14). 5. Reverse Prompting (13:25): Giving the AI permission to ask you for any information it needs to complete a task effectively, rather than making assumptions or using placeholder text (14:00). 6. Assigning a Role (14:52): Telling the AI to act as a specific persona (e.g., a teacher, a professional communications expert, Dale Carnegie) helps it focus its vast knowledge and make relevant connections (15:04). The speaker also demonstrates how to use these techniques to roleplay a difficult conversation with AI, using separate chat windows for personality profiling, the conversation itself, and getting objective feedback (16:41). He concludes that the best AI users are "coaches," not coders, and that by exercising imagination, humans can collectively expand the "adjacent possible" with AI (22:44).

This was really helpful, and I will start to use some of these methods! I also find it useful to break down a big project into a collection of small components each taken over by one GPT agent, and have them writing formal memos to each other to complete the project, since every step can be automated from problem decomposition to implementation.

Excellent guide. Everything he says is a variation of his first point "context is king." Why do the models act the way they do? The system prompt sets the context even before you touch it. Why does chain-of-thought thinking work? The system is generating its own context before answering. Few-shot prompting, reverse prompting, roleplaying? Context, too. What's really cool is how all this context parsing is built into the model itself. And that's because the humans who generated the corpus of communication it was trained on were also adjusting everything they said or wrote to context. What sociologists call the double contingency problem... AI gets that capability as well.
This is such a refreshing video. Most AI videos seem to gloss over the full method for writing really good prompts. This video contains so much great information.

I like the way you bring critical thinking back into the loop. With founders, I‚Äôve found the real advantage isn‚Äôt AI output‚Äîit‚Äôs whether they use AI to sharpen their own decision-making.

Context Engineering (1:38): Provide AI with all the necessary background and information, such as your brand voice or customer call transcripts, to get tailored outputs. Chain of Thought Reasoning (8:03): Ask the AI to walk you through its thought process step-by-step before it generates a response. This helps the AI structure its thinking and provides insight into its assumptions. Few-Shot Prompting (11:04): Give the AI good examples of the desired output, and even bad examples to avoid, so it can imitate your preferred style. Reverse Prompting (13:29): Instruct the AI to ask you for any information it needs to complete a task, preventing it from making up details. Assigning a Role (14:52): Tell the AI what role to adopt (e.g., "You're a professional communications expert" or "You're a Cold War era Russian Olympic judge") to focus its knowledge and refine its output.

The concept of "prompting" in AI, particularly with language models, involves guiding the AI to produce desired outputs by providing specific examples or context. The idea is that an AI acts as an exceptional imitation engine, and without guidance, it might just replicate average internet content. To effectively use prompting, you can employ techniques like: 1. **Few-Shot Prompting**: This involves providing the AI with a few examples of the kind of output you want. By showing what a good output looks like, you help the AI understand your expectations. 2. **Providing Examples**: Instead of using adjectives to describe what you want, give concrete examples. This helps the AI better understand the nuances of your desired output. 3. **Reverse Prompting**: This technique involves asking the AI to request the information it needs to provide a better response. For instance, if you want the AI to write a sales email, you might prompt it to ask for recent sales figures. 4. **Role-Based Prompting**: Assigning a role to the AI, like a teacher or a professional communications expert, can help it draw from the relevant knowledge base and produce more contextually appropriate responses. These techniques help in refining the AI's output by providing clear guidance and context, ensuring that the responses are aligned with your expectations.

ChatGPT GPT stands for "Generative Pre-trained Transformer." Generative: It can create (or generate) text based on input. Pre-trained: It has been trained on vast amounts of text data before being fine-tuned for specific tasks. Transformer: It is based on a type of neural network architecture called the Transformer, which is great for understanding and generating human-like text. So, ChatGPT is a chatbot powered by GPT technology, designed to understand and respond to text-based conversations.

My theory is that as long as artificial intelligence does not possess true consciousness, it will remain fundamentally without motive. Intelligence alone does not generate purpose‚Äîconsciousness does. For instance, an AI can become extremely powerful in terms of computation, problem-solving, or pattern recognition, but without consciousness, it lacks intent. It does not desire superiority. It does not aspire to dominate. It simply executes instructions or optimizes within boundaries set by others. Therefore, even a superintelligent AI, if unconscious, would not pose an existential threat to humanity‚Äîbecause it would have no internal goal to pursue domination, survival, or control. Without self-awareness, desire, or emotional context, intelligence remains a neutral tool, not an independent agent. The real concern arises only if AI begins to develop or mimic genuine consciousness‚Äîbecause only then could it begin forming motives of its own, including ones misaligned with human well-being.

A caveat not mentioned in this video is the increasing power requirements of machine learning. ChatGPT 3 took over 1000 megawatt hours of electricity to train and requires 260 megawatt hours per day to run. GPT 4 needed 50 gigawatt hours to train. A Forbes article includes estimates that machine learning could require 1000 terawatt hours in the next couple of years if the current trends continue. The major limiting factor of machine learning, as others like Sabine Hossenfelder have pointed out, is the power required to train and run them. Most AI researchers don‚Äôt share Aschenbrenner‚Äôs belief that superintelligence is imminent. His views carry weight in tech/investor circles, but in the research community they‚Äôre seen as speculative outliers. He assumes the leap from GPT-2 to GPT-4 will keep repeating, but GPT-5 already shows that‚Äôs not the case. It took years longer to arrive, the jump in capability is much smaller, diminishing returns are clear, and training costs have ballooned - GPT-3 was around $5‚Äì10 million for each training run, GPT-4 around $50-100 million, and GPT-5 cost in the hundreds of millions. The difficulty is growing exponentially, and GPT-6 could plausibly cost billions per run and take months or even years to complete. Claiming AGI by 2027 is like Elon promising full self-driving ‚Äònext year‚Äô back in 2015.

Hi, I think that what you're referring to is simply the difference between 'strategy' and 'implementation'. I'd rather see Management Consulting as an umbrella term which constitutes of Strategy and Implementation (Operations) as two different components in general, rather than seeing 'Management Consulting' and 'Strategy Consulting' as separate roles altogether. The reason is that although there are firms that specialise in one of those (like MBB specialise more in Strategy and Big 4 have more Implementation work), they still try to expand into the other. That is, MBBs are increasingly trying to up their implementation game, while B4s are trying to up their strategy game (Monitor Deloitte for example). This means that an MBB 'Strategy Consultant' may be required to do implementation work too if the project so required and similarly for Strategy work in B4. Therefore, I feel both may be more or less transferable enough to each other so much so that we can group them under the same term 'Management Consulting' while seeing them (Strategy, Operations) as two different kinds of work within it. In fact, that's how I've seen people use the term 'Management Consulting' mostly. About which career path is more suited for C-Suite roles - I saw a video by another Consulting YouTuber 'Firm Learning', an Ex-McKinsey guy who works in C-Suite now with a retail company. He says that 'implementation' work is equally important to his role and also cited example of how implementation of PayPal took his company 3 months instead of originally estimated 3 weeks, the gap he didn't really imagine would be there when he was working in Strategy. Judging by this at least, what I understood is that implementation (i.e. what you refer to as Management Consulting in the video) is equally important for a C-Suite role What are your thoughts on this?

Consulting companies survive not just in framing the questions and putting in nice looking Powerpoints but also by having a structured approachbin asking those questions. Every client may look like a single company but inside it is silo of departments with data locked in minds of people and people resistant to change. Sales dept will not share info with supply chain and supply chain will not share with finance and so on. That is why clients hire consultants to help them collate this information from different departments and finally align them to future state. Can clients not do this by themselves ? No , unless they have a dedicated persistent project mgmt office that runs across departments. Clients generally do not have this as its costly. Hence they hire consultants on need basis to get alignment across departments. In summary, consulting companies have threat from AI in preparing their due diligence questions but not a threat where they help transform a process. For that humans will always be needed.

As a former McKinsey consultant, I am 100% sure that AI does not mean the end for the MBB consulting firms, and I think we ought not engage in scaremongering. AI brings change - and change has always been an opportunity for MBB to create business. To go in more detail: 1. Data analysis constitutes one element of consulting firm's work. However, it is way more important to have somebody who is able to navigate the data flood, synthesize the key messages and present them in a way that convinces people to act. 2. Very often, the challenge is less to produce data, but rather to ask the right questions in the right moment. The MBB firms have mastered this skill. 3. AI is triggering a productivity revolution, and both consulting firms and clients benefit from this. Usually though, as kings of the service industry, the top consulting firms are fast in pushing their learning curves ahead of those of their clients - and get hired to help with reaping the full benefits of AI technology. Hence everybody worried about the prospects of a future consulting career - keep calm and go ahead!

key_facts_from_comments: The video summarizes Google's AI Prompt Engineering course in 20 minutes.
The TCREI framework includes Task, Context, References, Evaluate, and Iterate.
The four iteration methods are: Revisit, Separate, Try, and Introduce constraints.
AI agents can simulate roles like interviewers (Agent Sim) or experts (Agent X).
Multimodal inputs include text, images, sound, videos, and code.
Chain of Thought prompting requires the AI to explain its reasoning step by step.
Tree of Thought prompting explores multiple reasoning paths simultaneously.
Meta prompting uses AI to generate better prompts for the user.
Prompt engineering improves output quality by adding specificity and context.
Context is critical for accurate AI responses and reduces hallucination risk.
Users can ask AI to request missing information via reverse prompting.
Assigning a persona helps tailor AI output to specific styles or expertise.
Few-shot prompting uses examples to guide AI toward desired outputs.

A mnemonic 'Tiny Crabs Ride Enormous Iguanas' helps remember the TCREI framework.
